title: Towards the Giant Radio Array for Neutrino Detection (GRAND): the GRANDProto300 and GRAND@Auger prototypes
abstract:
The Giant Radio Array for Neutrino Detection (GRAND) is a proposed
multi-messenger observatory of ultra-high-energy (UHE) particles of cosmic
origin. Its main goal is to find the long-sought origin of UHE cosmic rays by
detecting large numbers of them and the secondary particles created by their
interaction -- gamma rays, and, especially, neutrinos. GRAND will do so using
large arrays of radio antennas that look for the radio signals emitted by the
air showers initiated by the interactions of the UHE particles in the
atmosphere. Since 2023, three small-scale prototype GRAND arrays have been in
operation: GRAND@Nan\c{c}ay in France, GRAND@Auger in Argentina, and
GRANDProto300 in China. Together, their goal is to validate the detection
principle of GRAND under prolonged field conditions, achieving efficient,
autonomous radio-detection of air showers. We describe the hardware, software,
layout, and operation of the GRAND prototypes and show the first radio spectra
measured by them. Despite challenges, the successful operation of the
prototypes confirms that the GRAND instrumentation is apt to address the goals
of the experiment and lays the groundwork for its ensuing stages.

1 Introduction
The Giant Radio Array for Neutrino Detection (GRAND) [1] is a planned multi-messenger obser-
vatory of ultra-high energy (UHE) particles of cosmic originâ€”cosmic rays, neutrinos, and gamma
rays. Its ultimate goal is to provide crucial evidence that addresses the long-standing question of
the origin of UHE cosmic rays (UHECRs) [2â€“4]. GRAND plans to do so, directly, by detecting a
vast number of UHECRs and, indirectly, by detecting the secondary gamma rays and, especially,
the UHE neutrinos made by the interaction of UHECRs [5]. To achieve this, GRAND plans to use
large arrays of radio antennas that search for the distinctive radio signals emitted by the extensive
air showers initiated by UHE particles interacting in the atmosphere [6, 7].
The radio-detection of UHECRs is a mature technique. It has been demonstrated in past
and present detectors using overground antenna arrays [6, 7] by the Auger Engineering Radio
Array (AERA) [8], the Low-Frequency Array (LOFAR) [9], the Taiwan Astroparticle Radiowave
Observatory for Geo-synchrotron Emissions (TAROGE) [10], and the Tianshan Radio Experiment
for Neutrino Detection (TREND) [11]; using underground arrays [12] by the Askaryan Radio
Array (ARA) [13] and the Antarctic Ross Ice Shelf Antenna Neutrino Array (ARIANNA) [14];

Their purpose is to validate two core requirements that GRAND must fulfill to achieve its goals.
First, the prototypes must validate the viability of autonomous radio-detection of air showers
in a sparse radio array [32â€“35], unaided by particle detectors, and despite the presence of natural
and anthropogenic radio background that may mimic the radio signatures expected from showers.
â€“ 2 â€“Second, the prototypes must validate that the arrays are able to operate under harsh environmental
field conditionsâ€”high temperature, sandstorms, rainstormsâ€”for prolonged periods of time. The
lessons garnered from the prototypes will inform the design of the experiment in later stages.
Inthispaper,weintroducethedesignandoperationoftheGRANDprototypearrays,focusing
on the two larger ones, GRANDProto300 (GP300) and GRAND@Auger (G@A). In addition,
we present the first results obtained by them during their first two years of operation: the time-
dependent and time-averaged radio spectra measured by them, including identified sources of
radio background.The ongoing operation of the arraysâ€”though not devoid of challengesâ€”
coupled with their early-data results, validate the resilience of the GRAND design to adapt to
different environmental conditions, a requirement to pursue future, larger stages of GRAND.
This constitutes the basis for demonstrating the autonomous detection of cosmic rays in GRAND,
which will be shown in future publications (see Ref. [35] for preliminary results).

4.1 Self-trigger algorithm
The main science case of GRANDâ€”the study of ultra-high-energy particles [1]â€”involves the
detection of extensive air showers. The radio emission from air showers induces a temporary

starts when the amplitude of the signal exceeds the preset â€œsignal threshold",i.e., when a signal crossing
happens, as long as there was no such crossing in the preceding quiet time window. In the time period
following the signal crossing, called the â€œtrigger period windowâ€, the algorithm counts the number of

allowed minimum and maximum values, and the time interval between any two adjacent noise-threshold
crossings does not exceed a predefined maximum value, the trigger process is completed and the signal is
accepted. Because the trigger logic runs under the 500-MHz clock in the FPGA, the timing has a resolution
of 2 ns. The time stamp, corresponding to the time of the end of the trigger period window, is recorded and
it is sent to the Central DAQ.

acquisition chain described above, this distortion is translated into a short transient in the voltage
inputtotheADC.However,anthropogenicsourcesalsoemitradiopulseswithsimilarcharacteristics.
Thus, air-shower experiments that rely solely on their radio-detection, like the GRAND prototype
arrays, must have a self-triggering procedure that selects only detected events that resemble those
expected from air showers.
The detected radio pulse emitted by an air shower generates a short-duration, high-amplitude
(relative to the average baseline) oscillation in the FEB output. Man-made noise usually creates
a wider pulse or a train of pulses. In addition, constructive interference of single-frequency
anthropogenic sources can also create air shower-like pulses. The Local Trigger happens at the
DU level and is implemented within the firmware running on the FPGA chip. Its aim is to select
air-shower candidates while rejecting background pulses by efficiently identifying peaks in the
differenceoftwoconsecutiveADCsamples. WiththeprototypeGRANDFEB,itispossibletofirst
remove single-frequency noise sources with a digital filter, as shown in Section 3.3. The resulting
filtered signal is fed to the trigger algorithm.
Figure 13 shows a representative flowchart of the trigger algorithm, which begins with a
configurable â€œsignal thresholdâ€. If the signal exceeds this threshold and there has not been any
threshold crossing in a time window prior to the current pulse, the algorithm starts. The signal
â€“ 16 â€“threshold is set to a value that is suitably higher than the average noise level, while maintaining a
reasonable trigger rate. The second of these conditions aims to avoid pulse trains. Next, in a time
window after the pulse, the system counts how many times a second â€œnoise thresholdâ€ is crossed.
The width of the time windows, the signal and noise threshold levels, the allowed maximum
number of crossings of the noise threshold, and the maximum time between successive crossings
are adjustable parameters. They are set offline at the Central DAQ prior to each data acquisition
run. The values are chosen to best reject long and/or irregular pulse trains, and to prevent digital
glitchesfromcorruptingthevoltagetraces. Thistriggerflexibilityallowsustoadapttothedifferent
noise environments of each array, with G@A requiring stricter settings to avoid the more frequent
narrow and broadband radio frequency interference (RFI). When all triggering conditions are met,
the Local Trigger is complete and the timestamp is sent to the Central DAQ.
Next to recording air showers, the arrays also keep track of the background conditions via
unbiasedtriggering. This corresponds to periodically recorded data, independent of the measured
voltage levels. Such unbiased data are suitable for monitoring the environment and for calibrating
the setups using the periodic variation of the Galactic noise, which is currently ongoing [30, 36].
Unbiased data can also be used for additional science cases like measuring fast radio bursts [48].
Unbiased triggering, by default, takes place once every 10 s (a pre-defined 20-Hz mode is also
available). In the G@A firmware version, it is possible to set the unbiased triggering frequency
between 1Hz and 100kHz. GP300 and G@A perform both transient and unbiased triggering.

5 Data storage
The final data files of each trigger typeâ€”CD, UD, and MDâ€”are saved on the local storage of the
Central DAQ computer in GP300 and G@A. For GP300, the binary files are sent in real time to a
computercenterinNanjing,China,throughawirelessbridge. Thefilesarethenmanuallymovedto
the CC-IN2P3 cluster in Lyon, France. For G@A, new files on disk are copied daily to the central
storage in CC-IN2P3 using the 4G network. This copying does not interfere with the data-taking
or the bandwidth used by the Pierre Auger Collaboration. In case of high RFI conditions or failed
off-site data transfer, the DAQ computer has enough memory to store all data.
The automatic copying requires a local bash script to run automatically (i.e., acronjob) on
the central computer for G@A and semi-manually for GP300. This script first searches for files
not already transferred to CC-IN2P3 and stores this list in a simple local SQLite database. This
â€“ 18 â€“database is used to keep track of previously transferred files and to determine if a file needs to be
sent. Afterwards,thenewdatafilesarerelayedtothecorrespondingdirectoriesonCC-IN2P3using
rsyncand then flagged into the local SQLite database.
When data dispatch is finalized, a second script is triggered in CC-IN2P3 that registers all
newly transferred files in the main database and launches the conversion into the GRANDRoot
format, described in Ref. [48]. The GRANDRoot files are moved to the corresponding directories
and registered in the main database.

8 Summary and perspectives
The Giant Radio Array for Neutrino Detection (GRAND) is a planned observatory of ultra-high-
energy particles of cosmic origin: cosmic rays, neutrinos, and gamma rays. GRAND aims to
detect the radio emission from air showers initiated by their interaction in the atmosphere using
large ground arrays of antennas. The next large deployment goal of GRAND is to have two arrays
consistingof10,000antennaseachintheNorthernandSouthernHemispheres. Toachievethis,the
GRANDCollaborationhasadoptedastagedapproachtodeployment,withthreeongoingprototype
arrays to test and validate the detection and reconstruction methods.
Three prototype arrays were deployed in 2023. GRAND@NanÃ§ay, in France, is a 4-antenna
arrayusedasatestbenchfortheCollaborationâ€™sEuropeanlaboratories. GRANDProto300,inChina,
hasgonethroughtwostagesofdeployment,fromaninitial13-antennastagetoitscurrent65-antenna
stage. These stages act as pathfinders for the future final 300-antenna array. GRAND@Auger, in
Argentina, stems from an agreement between the GRAND and the Pierre Auger Collaborations.
The 10-antenna array was deployed on modified AERA stations. In this paper, we focused on the
hardware, software, and early operation of GRANDProto300 and GRAND@Auger.
To adapt to local conditions and explore optimal designs for the final GRAND setup, the
prototype array at each site featured different key choices in hardware and software. Throughout
2023, the arrays, including their hardware, firmware, and DAQ software, were commissioned
using daily data monitoring. Operating these prototypes under prolonged field conditions exposed
hardware and software challenges that have been met.
â€“ 23 â€“GRANDProto300andGRAND@Augerhaveremainedlargelyoperationalforabouttwoyears.
Their data have been analyzed and understood. We have shown results based on these data that
demonstrate the adequacy of the GRAND experimental setup and provide an understanding of the
radiobackgroundpresentateachsite. ThedetectionoftheGalacticradioemissionâ€”thesearchfor
which is ongoing in both prototypesâ€”will refine the calibration of the GRAND detection units.
TheGRANDprototypeshavealreadyyieldedakeyresult: thattheperformanceoftheGRAND
detection units is similar at the two array sites, despite one having a radio background notably
higher than the other, and despite their differences in hardware and software. The demonstrated
resilience of the GRAND DU is not merely a technical achievement; it is a foundational scientific
result for the entire project. A future stage of GRAND consisting of arrays distributed in multiple
geographicallocationswillinevitablyfacediverseenvironmentalandradio-backgroundconditions.
Our finding that consistent performance can be achieved through adaptable hardware and software
confirms the feasibility of combining data from geographically distant arrays. This is essential for
achieving the full-sky coverage and large-scale exposure of future stages of GRAND.
The ultimate goal of GRANDProto300 and GRAND@Auger is to validate the autonomous
radio-detection of inclined extensive air showers in GRAND, expected from ultra-high-energy
cosmic rays, neutrinos, and gamma rays. This detection, triggered by no signal other than radio,
and with a high efficiency, is essential to the goals of GRAND. Presently, the data collected by
GRANDProto300 and GRAND@Auger are being searched for air showers initiated by ultra-high-
energy cosmic rays. In GRANDProto300, we have identified the first cosmic-ray candidates [38â€“
43]. In GRAND@Auger, the detection of cosmic-ray candidates is being validated through their
coincident detection by the Pierre Auger Observatory [47].

Abstract Content:
The Giant Radio Array for Neutrino Detection (GRAND) is a proposed
multi-messenger observatory of ultra-high-energy (UHE) particles of cosmic
origin. Its main goal is to find the long-sought origin of UHE cosmic rays by
detecting large numbers of them and the secondary particles created by their
interaction -- gamma rays, and, especially, neutrinos. GRAND will do so using
large arrays of radio antennas that look for the radio signals emitted by the
air showers initiated by the interactions of the UHE particles in the
atmosphere. Since 2023, three small-scale prototype GRAND arrays have been in
operation: GRAND@Nan\c{c}ay in France, GRAND@Auger in Argentina, and
GRANDProto300 in China. Together, their goal is to validate the detection
principle of GRAND under prolonged field conditions, achieving efficient,
autonomous radio-detection of air showers. We describe the hardware, software,
layout, and operation of the GRAND prototypes and show the first radio spectra
measured by them. Despite challenges, the successful operation of the
prototypes confirms that the GRAND instrumentation is apt to address the goals
of the experiment and lays the groundwork for its ensuing stages.

1 Introduction
The Giant Radio Array for Neutrino Detection (GRAND) [1] is a planned multi-messenger obser-
vatory of ultra-high energy (UHE) particles of cosmic originâ€”cosmic rays, neutrinos, and gamma
rays. Its ultimate goal is to provide crucial evidence that addresses the long-standing question of
the origin of UHE cosmic rays (UHECRs) [2â€“4]. GRAND plans to do so, directly, by detecting a
vast number of UHECRs and, indirectly, by detecting the secondary gamma rays and, especially,
the UHE neutrinos made by the interaction of UHECRs [5]. To achieve this, GRAND plans to use
large arrays of radio antennas that search for the distinctive radio signals emitted by the extensive
air showers initiated by UHE particles interacting in the atmosphere [6, 7].
The radio-detection of UHECRs is a mature technique. It has been demonstrated in past
and present detectors using overground antenna arrays [6, 7] by the Auger Engineering Radio
Array (AERA) [8], the Low-Frequency Array (LOFAR) [9], the Taiwan Astroparticle Radiowave
Observatory for Geo-synchrotron Emissions (TAROGE) [10], and the Tianshan Radio Experiment
for Neutrino Detection (TREND) [11]; using underground arrays [12] by the Askaryan Radio
Array (ARA) [13] and the Antarctic Ross Ice Shelf Antenna Neutrino Array (ARIANNA) [14];

4 Self-trigger and data acquisition
4.1 Self-trigger algorithm
The main science case of GRANDâ€”the study of ultra-high-energy particles [1]â€”involves the
detection of extensive air showers. The radio emission from air showers induces a temporary
â€“ 15 â€“Figure13.LocalTriggerflowforanincomingsignalataGRANDdetectionunit.Thetriggeralgorithm
starts when the amplitude of the signal exceeds the preset â€œsignal threshold",i.e., when a signal crossing
happens, as long as there was no such crossing in the preceding quiet time window. In the time period
following the signal crossing, called the â€œtrigger period windowâ€, the algorithm counts the number of
crossings of a lower â€œnoise threshold". If the number of noise-threshold crossings is between predefined
allowed minimum and maximum values, and the time interval between any two adjacent noise-threshold
crossings does not exceed a predefined maximum value, the trigger process is completed and the signal is
accepted. Because the trigger logic runs under the 500-MHz clock in the FPGA, the timing has a resolution
of 2 ns. The time stamp, corresponding to the time of the end of the trigger period window, is recorded and
it is sent to the Central DAQ.
distortion of the local electric field, with a duration of several nanoseconds. Through the data
acquisition chain described above, this distortion is translated into a short transient in the voltage
inputtotheADC.However,anthropogenicsourcesalsoemitradiopulseswithsimilarcharacteristics.
Thus, air-shower experiments that rely solely on their radio-detection, like the GRAND prototype
arrays, must have a self-triggering procedure that selects only detected events that resemble those
expected from air showers.
The detected radio pulse emitted by an air shower generates a short-duration, high-amplitude
(relative to the average baseline) oscillation in the FEB output. Man-made noise usually creates
a wider pulse or a train of pulses. In addition, constructive interference of single-frequency
anthropogenic sources can also create air shower-like pulses. The Local Trigger happens at the
DU level and is implemented within the firmware running on the FPGA chip. Its aim is to select
air-shower candidates while rejecting background pulses by efficiently identifying peaks in the

configurable â€œsignal thresholdâ€. If the signal exceeds this threshold and there has not been any

â€“ 16 â€“threshold is set to a value that is suitably higher than the average noise level, while maintaining a

voltage levels. Such unbiased data are suitable for monitoring the environment and for calibrating

Unbiased triggering, by default, takes place once every 10 s (a pre-defined 20-Hz mode is also
available). In the G@A firmware version, it is possible to set the unbiased triggering frequency
between 1Hz and 100kHz. GP300 and G@A perform both transient and unbiased triggering.

5 Data storage
The final data files of each trigger typeâ€”CD, UD, and MDâ€”are saved on the local storage of the
Central DAQ computer in GP300 and G@A. For GP300, the binary files are sent in real time to a
computercenterinNanjing,China,throughawirelessbridge. Thefilesarethenmanuallymovedto
the CC-IN2P3 cluster in Lyon, France. For G@A, new files on disk are copied daily to the central
storage in CC-IN2P3 using the 4G network. This copying does not interfere with the data-taking
or the bandwidth used by the Pierre Auger Collaboration. In case of high RFI conditions or failed
off-site data transfer, the DAQ computer has enough memory to store all data.
The automatic copying requires a local bash script to run automatically (i.e., acronjob) on
the central computer for G@A and semi-manually for GP300. This script first searches for files
not already transferred to CC-IN2P3 and stores this list in a simple local SQLite database. This
â€“ 18 â€“database is used to keep track of previously transferred files and to determine if a file needs to be
sent. Afterwards,thenewdatafilesarerelayedtothecorrespondingdirectoriesonCC-IN2P3using
rsyncand then flagged into the local SQLite database.
When data dispatch is finalized, a second script is triggered in CC-IN2P3 that registers all
newly transferred files in the main database and launches the conversion into the GRANDRoot
format, described in Ref. [48]. The GRANDRoot files are moved to the corresponding directories
and registered in the main database.

8 Summary and perspectives
The Giant Radio Array for Neutrino Detection (GRAND) is a planned observatory of ultra-high-
energy particles of cosmic origin: cosmic rays, neutrinos, and gamma rays. GRAND aims to
detect the radio emission from air showers initiated by their interaction in the atmosphere using
large ground arrays of antennas. The next large deployment goal of GRAND is to have two arrays
consistingof10,000antennaseachintheNorthernandSouthernHemispheres. Toachievethis,the
GRANDCollaborationhasadoptedastagedapproachtodeployment,withthreeongoingprototype
arrays to test and validate the detection and reconstruction methods.
Three prototype arrays were deployed in 2023. GRAND@NanÃ§ay, in France, is a 4-antenna
arrayusedasatestbenchfortheCollaborationâ€™sEuropeanlaboratories. GRANDProto300,inChina,
hasgonethroughtwostagesofdeployment,fromaninitial13-antennastagetoitscurrent65-antenna
stage. These stages act as pathfinders for the future final 300-antenna array. GRAND@Auger, in
Argentina, stems from an agreement between the GRAND and the Pierre Auger Collaborations.
The 10-antenna array was deployed on modified AERA stations. In this paper, we focused on the
hardware, software, and early operation of GRANDProto300 and GRAND@Auger.
To adapt to local conditions and explore optimal designs for the final GRAND setup, the
prototype array at each site featured different key choices in hardware and software. Throughout
2023, the arrays, including their hardware, firmware, and DAQ software, were commissioned
using daily data monitoring. Operating these prototypes under prolonged field conditions exposed
hardware and software challenges that have been met.

Their data have been analyzed and understood. We have shown results based on these data that
demonstrate the adequacy of the GRAND experimental setup and provide an understanding of the
radiobackgroundpresentateachsite. ThedetectionoftheGalacticradioemissionâ€”thesearchfor
which is ongoing in both prototypesâ€”will refine the calibration of the GRAND detection units.
TheGRANDprototypeshavealreadyyieldedakeyresult: thattheperformanceoftheGRAND
detection units is similar at the two array sites, despite one having a radio background notably
higher than the other, and despite their differences in hardware and software. The demonstrated
resilience of the GRAND DU is not merely a technical achievement; it is a foundational scientific
result for the entire project. A future stage of GRAND consisting of arrays distributed in multiple
geographicallocationswillinevitablyfacediverseenvironmentalandradio-backgroundconditions.
Our finding that consistent performance can be achieved through adaptable hardware and software
confirms the feasibility of combining data from geographically distant arrays. This is essential for
achieving the full-sky coverage and large-scale exposure of future stages of GRAND.
The ultimate goal of GRANDProto300 and GRAND@Auger is to validate the autonomous
radio-detection of inclined extensive air showers in GRAND, expected from ultra-high-energy
cosmic rays, neutrinos, and gamma rays. This detection, triggered by no signal other than radio,
and with a high efficiency, is essential to the goals of GRAND. Presently, the data collected by
GRANDProto300 and GRAND@Auger are being searched for air showers initiated by ultra-high-
energy cosmic rays. In GRANDProto300, we have identified the first cosmic-ray candidates [38â€“
43]. In GRAND@Auger, the detection of cosmic-ray candidates is being validated through their
coincident detection by the Pierre Auger Observatory [47].

title: Decaying superfluid turbulence near an anomalous non-thermal fixed point
abstract:
Anomalously slow coarsening in a dilute two-dimensional (2d) superfluid --
associated with a non-thermal fixed point in the closed system's universal
dynamics and driven by three-vortex collisions which initiate vortex-pair
annihilations -- is found to exhibit spatial scaling characteristics of
Kraichnan-Kolmogorov turbulence. During a universal interval, when the
characteristic length scale related to the inter-defect distance grows as
$\ell_\text{v}\sim t^{\,\beta}$, with $\beta\approx1/5$, moments of the
superfluid velocity circulation around an area of extent $r$ scale as predicted
by classical turbulence theory, $\Gamma^{p}(r)\sim r^{4p/3}$. Intermittency
corrections seen for higher values of $p$ are found to be consistent with
values measured for fully developed, classical turbulence. Hence, we link the
decaying quantum turbulence cascade in a closed superfluid to universal
dynamics close to a non-thermal fixed point. The decay exponent $\beta$ clearly
deviates from values known for classical systems.

Introduction.â€”Fluid turbulence has been among the first
systems used to study spatial and temporal scaling phenom-
ena in nature [1â€“7]. In three spatial dimensions, driven, fully
developed turbulence has been characterized as a direct cas-
cade, in which kinetic energy is transferred from large to small
spatial scales through an inertial range, establishing the sta-
tionary spectral distributionE(k)âˆ¼k âˆ’5/3. In contrast, re-
stricting the dynamics to a (quasi-)2d geometry, the energy
is transported in the opposite direction as large-scale eddies
are formed from smaller ones, which forms an inverse cas-
cade, giving rise to the same stationary algebraic momentum
distribution,E(k)âˆ¼k âˆ’5/3 [8â€“10]. On scales where quantum
statistics and coherence prevail, superfluid or quantum turbu-
lence emerges in inviscid superfluids, including 4He and di-
lute Bose-Einstein condensates [11â€“14]. The elementary con-
stituents of the flow are quantum vortices, carrying point-like
vorticity with discrete valuesqh/m,qâˆˆZ. They thus differ
from classical eddies in their microscopic properties, while
on large scales certain characteristics of classical fluid turbu-
lence, like the inverse energy cascade (IEC) in two dimen-
sions, have been recovered in superfluids [15â€“17].
While the standard setting discussed is fully developed tur-
bulence, where the driving introduces as much energy per
unit time as is lost at the dissipative end of the inertial range,
e.g., to thermal excitations, other scenarios of interest are the
buildup and decay of a turbulent cascade. Of particular rele-
vance in this regard is the evolution within a closed system,
i.e., without energy and particle gain and loss. As for classi-
cal 3d [18, 19] as well as 2d turbulence [20â€“32] the decay of
turbulence has been discussed for and measured in quantum
systems, cf., e.g., [33, 34]. In 2d, studies of decaying quan-
tum turbulence have focused on Onsager-Kraichnan conden-
sation of vortex clusters and the loss of vortex-antivortex pairs
[35â€“37], the direct enstrophy cascade [38], and finite temper-
atures [39]. The latter work examined the scaling evolution
of single-particle spectra, vortex number, and inter-defect dis-
tance, characterizing the vortex decay and scaling evolution

â€ t.gasenzer@uni-heidelberg.de
as universal dynamics near a non-thermal fixed point (NTFP)
[40â€“44], see [39, 45â€“62] in the context of vortex dynamics.
In analogy to the theory of equilibrium critical phenomena,
universal scaling dynamics has been proposed to be associ-
ated with NTFPs, see [63â€“66] for overviews. These fixed
points are thought to result from considering time evolution
as a renormalization-group flow, classifying space-time scal-
ing based on symmetries and the character of the field config-
urations. Recent experiments have explored various phenom-
ena and properties of universal space-time scaling, largely in
ultracold gases [15, 67â€“77].
Main result.â€”We show that the appearance of the anoma-
lous NTFP in a dilute 2d superfluid [51, 62] is directly re-
lated to the decay of quantum turbulence, exhibiting long-
range spatial scaling of the second moment of velocity circu-
lationÎ“according to the Kolmogorov-Kraichnan power-law
Î“2(r)âˆ¼r 8/3. Moreover, we find the scaling of higher mo-
ments of the velocity circulation to show intermittent devia-
tions consistent with the bifractal intermittency model studied
in stationary IECs [78, 79]. In contrast, vortex separation is
found to remain Gaussian distributed throughout the universal
dynamics and does not exhibit intermittent behavior in time.
In turn, the decaying 2d quantum turbulence in the closed sys-
tem is characterized by a growth of the inter-defect distance,
â„“v âˆ¼t Î², with an anomalously small, subdiffusive exponent
Î²â‰ˆ1/5, distinctly smaller than what is known from classical
turbulence [80]. The vortex pattern coarsening is associated
with an inverse cascade of the kinetic energy of incompress-
ible fluid flow, exhibiting classical scaling, which decays and
thereby expands further to lower momenta according to the
conservation law associated with the NTFP. Our results link
superfluid turbulence in a closed 2d system, on the grounds of
a high-resolution analysis in the spatial domain, to the concept
of NTFPs in far-from-equilibrium dynamics.
Non-thermal fixed points vs. turbulence.â€”For single-com-
ponent, scalar quantum field theories universal dynamics near
NTFPs is usually dominated by nonlinear excitations of the to-
tal density such as vortices, solitons, or kinks [15, 39, 45â€“62].
The spatio-temporal coarsening of the field pattern is reflected
in the loss of these excitations, and the length scaleâ„“(t)âˆ¼t Î²
is typically associated with the mean inter-defect distance. In
quasi-2d Bose gases, two distinct scaling exponents,Î²â‰ˆ1/5

Conclusions.â€”Starting from a large, randomly sampled
vortex ensemble with net zero circulation in a dilute 2d su-
perfluid Bose gas, we show that its dynamics in a closed sys-
tem develops the spatial scaling characteristics of an inverse
Kraichnan-Kolmogorov cascade. The temporal loss of defects
due to vortex annihilations implies that the single-particle mo-
mentum distribution of the Bose gas self-similarly shifts to
smaller wave numbers, thereby increasing the number of quasi
condensate particles at the lowest momenta, signalling the ap-
proach of universal dynamics close to a NTFP. The evolution
thus bears the characteristics of decaying 2d turbulence, in
which the vortex pattern exhibits coarsening, with an alge-
braic increase of the mean inter-vortex distance asâ„“ v(t)âˆ¼t Î².
The temporal coarsening exponent approachesÎ²â‰ˆ1/5 dur-
ing the same period of time when the spatial velocity circula-5
tion scales asÎ“(r)âˆ¼r 4/3, indicating decaying Kraichnan-type
turbulence. This exponent is distinctly smaller than what is
found in classical 2d turbulence for the dominant three-vortex
scattering,Î²â‰ˆ0.35, cf. [20, 28, 30, 80]. Moreover, thepth-
order moments ofÎ“show intermittent deviations from scaling
asâˆ¼r 4p/3 , which is found to match intermittency in classical
non-decaying IECs [78, 79]. In contrast, the temporal scal-
ing of the average inter-defect distance was found to be non-
intermittent up top=11. Our results demonstrate a close
connection between NTFPs and turbulence in quantum fluids.
They strongly motivate further research into the relevance of
NTFPs in classical fluid turbulence.

Abstract Content:
Anomalously slow coarsening in a dilute two-dimensional (2d) superfluid --
associated with a non-thermal fixed point in the closed system's universal
dynamics and driven by three-vortex collisions which initiate vortex-pair
annihilations -- is found to exhibit spatial scaling characteristics of
Kraichnan-Kolmogorov turbulence. During a universal interval, when the
characteristic length scale related to the inter-defect distance grows as
$\ell_\text{v}\sim t^{\,\beta}$, with $\beta\approx1/5$, moments of the
superfluid velocity circulation around an area of extent $r$ scale as predicted
by classical turbulence theory, $\Gamma^{p}(r)\sim r^{4p/3}$. Intermittency
corrections seen for higher values of $p$ are found to be consistent with
values measured for fully developed, classical turbulence. Hence, we link the
decaying quantum turbulence cascade in a closed superfluid to universal
dynamics close to a non-thermal fixed point. The decay exponent $\beta$ clearly
deviates from values known for classical systems.

Introduction.â€”Fluid turbulence has been among the first
systems used to study spatial and temporal scaling phenom-
ena in nature [1â€“7]. In three spatial dimensions, driven, fully
developed turbulence has been characterized as a direct cas-
cade, in which kinetic energy is transferred from large to small
spatial scales through an inertial range, establishing the sta-
tionary spectral distributionE(k)âˆ¼k âˆ’5/3. In contrast, re-
stricting the dynamics to a (quasi-)2d geometry, the energy
is transported in the opposite direction as large-scale eddies
are formed from smaller ones, which forms an inverse cas-
cade, giving rise to the same stationary algebraic momentum
distribution,E(k)âˆ¼k âˆ’5/3 [8â€“10]. On scales where quantum
statistics and coherence prevail, superfluid or quantum turbu-
lence emerges in inviscid superfluids, including 4He and di-
lute Bose-Einstein condensates [11â€“14]. The elementary con-
stituents of the flow are quantum vortices, carrying point-like
vorticity with discrete valuesqh/m,qâˆˆZ. They thus differ
from classical eddies in their microscopic properties, while
on large scales certain characteristics of classical fluid turbu-
lence, like the inverse energy cascade (IEC) in two dimen-
sions, have been recovered in superfluids [15â€“17].
While the standard setting discussed is fully developed tur-
bulence, where the driving introduces as much energy per
unit time as is lost at the dissipative end of the inertial range,
e.g., to thermal excitations, other scenarios of interest are the
buildup and decay of a turbulent cascade. Of particular rele-
vance in this regard is the evolution within a closed system,

of single-particle spectra, vortex number, and inter-defect dis-
tance, characterizing the vortex decay and scaling evolution

Conclusions.â€”Starting from a large, randomly sampled
vortex ensemble with net zero circulation in a dilute 2d su-
perfluid Bose gas, we show that its dynamics in a closed sys-
tem develops the spatial scaling characteristics of an inverse
Kraichnan-Kolmogorov cascade. The temporal loss of defects
due to vortex annihilations implies that the single-particle mo-
mentum distribution of the Bose gas self-similarly shifts to
smaller wave numbers, thereby increasing the number of quasi
condensate particles at the lowest momenta, signalling the ap-
proach of universal dynamics close to a NTFP. The evolution
thus bears the characteristics of decaying 2d turbulence, in
which the vortex pattern exhibits coarsening, with an alge-
braic increase of the mean inter-vortex distance asâ„“ v(t)âˆ¼t Î².
The temporal coarsening exponent approachesÎ²â‰ˆ1/5 dur-
ing the same period of time when the spatial velocity circula-5
tion scales asÎ“(r)âˆ¼r 4/3, indicating decaying Kraichnan-type
turbulence. This exponent is distinctly smaller than what is
found in classical 2d turbulence for the dominant three-vortex
scattering,Î²â‰ˆ0.35, cf. [20, 28, 30, 80]. Moreover, thepth-
order moments ofÎ“show intermittent deviations from scaling
asâˆ¼r 4p/3 , which is found to match intermittency in classical
non-decaying IECs [78, 79]. In contrast, the temporal scal-
ing of the average inter-defect distance was found to be non-
intermittent up top=11. Our results demonstrate a close
connection between NTFPs and turbulence in quantum fluids.
They strongly motivate further research into the relevance of
NTFPs in classical fluid turbulence.

title: Probing Light Dark Matter with Cosmic Gravitational Focusing
abstract:
We investigate the possibility of using the cosmic gravitational focusing
(CGF) to probe the minor light dark matter (DM) component whose mass is in the
range of $(0.1 \sim 100)$\,eV. Being a purely gravitational effect, the CGF
offers a mode-independent probe that is complementary to the existing ways such
as Lyman-$\alpha$ and $\Delta N_{\rm eff}$. Such effect finally leads to a
dipole density distribution that would affect the galaxy formation and hence
can be reconstructed with galaxy surveys such as DESI. Both the free-streaming
and clustering limits have been studied with analytical formulas while the
region in between is bridged with interpolation. We show the projected
sensitivity at DESI with the typical phase space distribution of a freeze-in DM
scenario as illustration.

Introductionâ€“ The DM plays very important roles
in the evolution and structure formation of our Universe
[1â€“3]. For redshiftzâ‰³10 when the dark energy has
not started to dominate, the behavior and history of our
Universe is mainly determined by radiation and matter.
Of the later, more than 80% are contributed by DM while
the remaining by the ordinary matter. To be exact, DM
is more than 5 times of the ordinary matter. It is then
a fair question to ask whether the DM has just a single
type or actually possesses multiple components. Since
the ordinary matter world is already a combination of
various isotopes that are formed by at least three building
blocks (proton, neutron, and electron), it is natural for
the DM sector to also have several species.
The particle physics provides various DM candidates
[4, 5] that are not just conceptually neat with unified
quantum field theory description in the same way as the
ordinary matter but also very simple with typically just
mass and coupling strength as the only parameters to
explain the observed DM phenomena from both astron-
omy and cosmology. Of them, the particular interest-
ing ones include the Weakly Interacting Massive Parti-
cles (WIMP) [6â€“10] that participate the weak gauge in-
teractions with mass typically at GeVâˆ¼TeV, the sterile
neutrino at keV scale [11â€“19] suggested by the observed
anomalies in neutrino oscillation experiments and astro-
physical observations, and the axion [20â€“22] motivated
by the strong CP problem with even lighter mass. The
mass spectrum of particle DM candidates spans around
100 orders from the smallest fuzzy DM at 10âˆ’22 eV to the
astrophysical primordial black holes (PBH) with masses
of 1050 g (âˆ¼10 88 eV) [23]. It is possible for the DM can-
didates to have totally different masses.
Besides mass, another important property is whether
the DM is cold, warm, or even hot [24]. It can have sig-
nificant effect on the large scale structure (LSS) of our
Universe today. The comparison between the galaxy sur-
vey and the theoretical N-body simulation shows strong
preference of the cold DM (CDM) [25â€“28]. Such conclu-
sion is sometimes strengthened to a claim that DM has
to be cold. Nevertheless, this is based on the assumption
that there is just one DM type. If the DM sector has
multiple components, it is perfectly fine to have CDM as
the major component with some warm DM (WDM) as a
minor contribution. Especially, a mixture of CDM and
WDM can help solving the small scale problem [29, 30].
The small-scale effect of WDM can be probed by
Lyman-Î±[31â€“33], Milk Way satellite galaxies [34], weak
lensing [35], strong lensing [36â€“38], galaxy UV luminosity
function [39â€“41], and stellar streams [42, 43]. If DM is a
fermion, it should also be subject to the fermion degen-
erate gas (Tremaine-Gunn) constraints at the galaxy [44]
and cosmological [45] levels. These observations require
the WDM massm WDM â‰³O(1) keV. Therefore, the light
WDM with mass below keV can contribute only a frac-
tion of the total DM. The mixed DM scenario with both
CDM and WDM, has been widely explored [29, 30, 46â€“62]
with various models [63â€“67]. The current Lyman-Î±gives
a constraint on the WDM fractionF WDM <O(0.1) for
the light DM massm WDM <100 eV [68]. If the WDM
mass belowm WDM <O(1) eV, it remains nearly rela-
tivistic around recombination and consequently it will
also be subject to the constraint on the effective degree
of freedom (âˆ†Neff) at the cosmic microwave background
(CMB) [69]. The light species has also been named as
hot DM such as [46, 70â€“89], before the neutrino oscilla-
tion was established in 1998.
In this letter, we explore the possibility of using the
cosmic gravitational focusing (CGF) to probe the minor
light DM component. Similar as the cosmic neutrinos
[90â€“95], a light DMXcan also develop a relative bulk
velocityv Xc â‰¡v X âˆ’v c with respect to the major CDM
(c). Then the light DM fluid can be focused when passing
by the CDM halo and develop a density dipole that can
be traced and reconstructed through the cross correla-
tion between galaxies of different types [90, 94]. Being a
purely gravitational effect, the CGF effect can serve as a
model-independent method for for probing the light DM.

Conclusion and Discussionsâ€“ Although the large
scale structure of our Universe prefers the cold DM, a
light species can still exist as minor component so long as
its energy fraction is small enough. However, this leads
to an imaginable difficulty of probing such minor light
DM component.
Fortunately, if the minor light DM and the major cold
DM have quite different masses, they would develop rel-
ative bulk velocity. Consequently, the light DM fluid
would flow by the cold DM halos and the gravitational
attraction between them would lead to the cosmic grav-
itational effect in the same way as the cosmic neutrino
fluid. However, the light DM with larger mass would have
much stronger effect than its neutrino counterparts. This
makes the CGF an ideal tool for probing the light DM.
We provide analytical understanding of the sensitiv-
ity scaling behaviors with the light DM massm X in
both the free-streaming (m X â‰²1 eV) and clustering
(mX â‰³10 eV) limits. Our study shows that for the light
DM mass 1 eV< m X <10 eV, the projected CGF sen-
sitivity with the DESI observation can reachF X â‰²10 âˆ’3
which stronger than the existing Lyman-Î±and CMB
âˆ†Neff constraints by two orders. With the upcoming
galaxy surveys, such as the spectroscopic survey DESI
[115, 120] as well as the photometric surveys like LSST
[121], WFIRST [122], Euclid [123], and CSST [124â€“126],
we expect the CGF effect to receive emerging firm data.

Abstract Content:
We investigate the possibility of using the cosmic gravitational focusing
(CGF) to probe the minor light dark matter (DM) component whose mass is in the
range of $(0.1 \sim 100)$\,eV. Being a purely gravitational effect, the CGF
offers a mode-independent probe that is complementary to the existing ways such
as Lyman-$\alpha$ and $\Delta N_{\rm eff}$. Such effect finally leads to a
dipole density distribution that would affect the galaxy formation and hence
can be reconstructed with galaxy surveys such as DESI. Both the free-streaming
and clustering limits have been studied with analytical formulas while the
region in between is bridged with interpolation. We show the projected
sensitivity at DESI with the typical phase space distribution of a freeze-in DM
scenario as illustration.

Probing Light Dark Matter with Cosmic Gravitational Focusing
Shao-Feng Ge 1, 2,âˆ— and Liang Tan 1, 2,â€ 
1State Key Laboratory of Dark Matter Physics, Tsung-Dao Lee Institute
& School of Physics and Astronomy, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, China
2Key Laboratory for Particle Astrophysics and Cosmology (MOE)
& Shanghai Key Laboratory for Particle Physics and Cosmology,
Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, China
We investigate the possibility of using the cosmic gravitational focusing (CGF) to probe the minor
light dark matter (DM) component whose mass is in the range of (0.1âˆ¼100) eV. Being a purely
gravitational effect, the CGF offers a mode-independent probe that is complementary to the existing
ways such as Lyman-Î±and âˆ†N eff. Such effect finally leads to a dipole density distribution that
would affect the galaxy formation and hence can be reconstructed with galaxy surveys such as DESI.
Both the free-streaming and clustering limits have been studied with analytical formulas while the
region in between is bridged with interpolation. We show the projected sensitivity at DESI with
the typical phase space distribution of a freeze-in DM scenario as illustration.
Introductionâ€“ The DM plays very important roles
in the evolution and structure formation of our Universe
[1â€“3]. For redshiftzâ‰³10 when the dark energy has
not started to dominate, the behavior and history of our
Universe is mainly determined by radiation and matter.
Of the later, more than 80% are contributed by DM while
the remaining by the ordinary matter. To be exact, DM
is more than 5 times of the ordinary matter. It is then
a fair question to ask whether the DM has just a single
type or actually possesses multiple components. Since
the ordinary matter world is already a combination of
various isotopes that are formed by at least three building
blocks (proton, neutron, and electron), it is natural for
the DM sector to also have several species.
The particle physics provides various DM candidates
[4, 5] that are not just conceptually neat with unified
quantum field theory description in the same way as the
ordinary matter but also very simple with typically just
mass and coupling strength as the only parameters to
explain the observed DM phenomena from both astron-
omy and cosmology. Of them, the particular interest-
ing ones include the Weakly Interacting Massive Parti-
cles (WIMP) [6â€“10] that participate the weak gauge in-
teractions with mass typically at GeVâˆ¼TeV, the sterile
neutrino at keV scale [11â€“19] suggested by the observed
anomalies in neutrino oscillation experiments and astro-
physical observations, and the axion [20â€“22] motivated
by the strong CP problem with even lighter mass. The
mass spectrum of particle DM candidates spans around
100 orders from the smallest fuzzy DM at 10âˆ’22 eV to the
astrophysical primordial black holes (PBH) with masses
of 1050 g (âˆ¼10 88 eV) [23]. It is possible for the DM can-
didates to have totally different masses.
Besides mass, another important property is whether
the DM is cold, warm, or even hot [24]. It can have sig-
nificant effect on the large scale structure (LSS) of our
Universe today. The comparison between the galaxy sur-
vey and the theoretical N-body simulation shows strong
preference of the cold DM (CDM) [25â€“28]. Such conclu-
sion is sometimes strengthened to a claim that DM has
to be cold. Nevertheless, this is based on the assumption
that there is just one DM type. If the DM sector has
multiple components, it is perfectly fine to have CDM as
the major component with some warm DM (WDM) as a
minor contribution. Especially, a mixture of CDM and
WDM can help solving the small scale problem [29, 30].
The small-scale effect of WDM can be probed by
Lyman-Î±[31â€“33], Milk Way satellite galaxies [34], weak
lensing [35], strong lensing [36â€“38], galaxy UV luminosity
function [39â€“41], and stellar streams [42, 43]. If DM is a
fermion, it should also be subject to the fermion degen-
erate gas (Tremaine-Gunn) constraints at the galaxy [44]
and cosmological [45] levels. These observations require
the WDM massm WDM â‰³O(1) keV. Therefore, the light
WDM with mass below keV can contribute only a frac-
tion of the total DM. The mixed DM scenario with both
CDM and WDM, has been widely explored [29, 30, 46â€“62]
with various models [63â€“67]. The current Lyman-Î±gives
a constraint on the WDM fractionF WDM <O(0.1) for
the light DM massm WDM <100 eV [68]. If the WDM
mass belowm WDM <O(1) eV, it remains nearly rela-
tivistic around recombination and consequently it will
also be subject to the constraint on the effective degree

Conclusion and Discussionsâ€“ Although the large
scale structure of our Universe prefers the cold DM, a
light species can still exist as minor component so long as
its energy fraction is small enough. However, this leads
to an imaginable difficulty of probing such minor light
DM component.
Fortunately, if the minor light DM and the major cold
DM have quite different masses, they would develop rel-
ative bulk velocity. Consequently, the light DM fluid
would flow by the cold DM halos and the gravitational
attraction between them would lead to the cosmic grav-
itational effect in the same way as the cosmic neutrino
fluid. However, the light DM with larger mass would have
much stronger effect than its neutrino counterparts. This
makes the CGF an ideal tool for probing the light DM.
We provide analytical understanding of the sensitiv-
ity scaling behaviors with the light DM massm X in
both the free-streaming (m X â‰²1 eV) and clustering
(mX â‰³10 eV) limits. Our study shows that for the light
DM mass 1 eV< m X <10 eV, the projected CGF sen-
sitivity with the DESI observation can reachF X â‰²10 âˆ’3
which stronger than the existing Lyman-Î±and CMB
âˆ†Neff constraints by two orders. With the upcoming
galaxy surveys, such as the spectroscopic survey DESI
[115, 120] as well as the photometric surveys like LSST
[121], WFIRST [122], Euclid [123], and CSST [124â€“126],
we expect the CGF effect to receive emerging firm data.

title: Radiation of "breathing" vortex electron packets in magnetic field
abstract:
When a vortex electron with an orbital angular momentum (OAM) enters a
magnetic field, its quantum state is described with a nonstationary
Laguerre-Gaussian (NSLG) state rather than with a stationary Landau state. A
key feature of these NSLG states is oscillations of the electron wave packet's
root-mean-square (r.m.s.) radius, similar to betatron oscillations.
Classically, such an oscillating charge distribution is expected to emit
photons. This raises a critical question: does this radiation carry away OAM,
leading to a loss of the electron's vorticity? To investigate this, we solve
Maxwell's equations using the charge and current densities derived from an
electron in the NSLG state. We calculate the total radiated power and the
angular momentum of the emitted field, quantifying the rate at which a vortex
electron loses its energy and OAM while propagating in a longitudinal magnetic
field. We find both the radiated power and the angular momentum losses to be
negligible indicating that linear accelerators (linacs) appear to be a
prominent tool for maintaining vorticity of relativistic vortex electrons and
other charged particles, at least in the quasi-classical approximation.

a stationary Landau state. A key feature of these NSLG states is oscillations of the electron wave

this radiation carry away OAM, leading to a loss of the electronâ€™s vorticity? To investigate this,
we solve Maxwellâ€™s equations using the charge and current densities derived from an electron in
the NSLG state. We calculate the total radiated power and the angular momentum of the emitted
field, quantifying the rate at which a vortex electron loses its energy and OAM while propagating
in a longitudinal magnetic field. We find both the radiated power and the angular momentum

I. INTRODUCTION
Vortex, or twisted, electrons are electrons in specific
quantum states with a definite projection of an orbital
angular momentum (OAM) along their propagation axis
[1â€“3]. Their OAM results in a magnetic moment that can
significantly exceed its spin-originated counterpart. This
property makes vortex electrons promising for numerous
applications in material science, chemistry, and particle
physics [3â€“5]. However, in particle physics, specifically,
electrons are required with energies in the GeV range,
whereas the highest energy achieved for a vortex electron
to date is only about 300 keV [3, 6, 7].
A straightforward approach to obtaining high-energy
vortex electrons is to first generate twisted electrons at
low energies and then accelerate them. While the curvi-
linear sections of accelerators are likely unsuitable since
they lack axial symmetry, linear accelerators (linacs) ap-
pear to be appropriate for this purpose. However, a crit-
ical question arises: do these particles preserve their vor-
ticity as they travel through the acceleratorâ€™s electromag-
netic fields? Specifically, could the small but inevitable
radiation losses in a linac lead to a significant decrease
in the particleâ€™s OAM?
Here we make a very first step towards addressing this
question by employing a semiclassical approach for find-

linacs can be considered a robust and reliable platform

at least within a quasi-classical approximation.

IV. DISCUSSION
Our semiclassical approach, which treats the electronâ€™s
wave function as a coherent â€charge cloudâ€, is central
to an ongoing debate in the literature on how to model
single-particle radiation [22â€“25]. An alternative perspec-
tive suggests an incoherent model, where radiation in-
tensity is integrated over the probability distribution.
Experimentally distinguishing between these competing
theoretical frameworks â€” for instance, using a TEM â€”
remains a crucial open challenge and a promising direc-
tion for future research.
Our semiclassical results must also be considered in the
context of a full QED treatment, which includes sponta-
neous quantum transitions between energy levels â€”â€“ a
channel absent in our model. We hypothesize that a rig-
orous QED calculation for an NSLG state would reveal
both this â€quantumâ€ radiation and the classical compo-
nent from the wave packetâ€™s dynamics. This raises funda-
mental questions about how these two contributions are
encoded within QED, whether they can be separated,
and how they might interfere.
Plausibly, for â€sufficiently nonstationaryâ€ states, the
â€classicalâ€ radiation mechanism we describe might dom-
inate over the â€œquantumâ€ one. A critical open question is
the quantitative criterion for this classical regime, which
is supposed to be a condition likeÏƒ st âˆ’Ïƒ L â‰«Ïƒ L.
A final practical consideration is the radiation from the
solenoidâ€™s fringe fields. As detailed in Appendix C, the
inhomogeneous fields in this region generate a transient
burst of radiation with possibly high values of angular
momentum as the electron enters and exits. Crucially,
this transition signal is experimentally distinguishable
from the continuous, periodic radiation generated within
the uniform field. This separation allows for a clear ex-
perimental test of our central predictions for the steady-
state emission.8
V. CONCLUSION
In this work, we have developed a semiclassical model
to investigate the radiation emitted by a vortex elec-
tron propagating through a longitudinal magnetic field,
such as in a linear accelerator. Our key finding is that
both the radiated energy and the change in the electronâ€™s
OAM are extremely small for realistic accelerator param-
eters. Even when extrapolated to a kilometer-scale linac,
the total energy radiated remains a negligible fraction of
the electronâ€™s transverse energy, which in turn validates
our semiclassical approach. More importantly, the total
change in OAM is found to be minuscule, far less than a
single quantum ofâ„. In other words, we have found that
a single quantum of OAM is emitted in a typical time of
at least 103 seconds, much longer than the acceleration
time even in a km-long linac.
We therefore arrive at a clear and impactful conclu-
sion: the orbital angular momentum of vortex electrons
is remarkably robust during acceleration in linacs. This
result strongly supports the viability of using linacs to
produce high-energy, relativistic vortex electron beams
for future applications in materials science and particle
physics.

Abstract Content:
When a vortex electron with an orbital angular momentum (OAM) enters a
magnetic field, its quantum state is described with a nonstationary
Laguerre-Gaussian (NSLG) state rather than with a stationary Landau state. A
key feature of these NSLG states is oscillations of the electron wave packet's
root-mean-square (r.m.s.) radius, similar to betatron oscillations.
Classically, such an oscillating charge distribution is expected to emit
photons. This raises a critical question: does this radiation carry away OAM,
leading to a loss of the electron's vorticity? To investigate this, we solve
Maxwell's equations using the charge and current densities derived from an
electron in the NSLG state. We calculate the total radiated power and the
angular momentum of the emitted field, quantifying the rate at which a vortex
electron loses its energy and OAM while propagating in a longitudinal magnetic
field. We find both the radiated power and the angular momentum losses to be
negligible indicating that linear accelerators (linacs) appear to be a
prominent tool for maintaining vorticity of relativistic vortex electrons and
other charged particles, at least in the quasi-classical approximation.

I. INTRODUCTION
Vortex, or twisted, electrons are electrons in specific
quantum states with a definite projection of an orbital
angular momentum (OAM) along their propagation axis
[1â€“3]. Their OAM results in a magnetic moment that can
significantly exceed its spin-originated counterpart. This
property makes vortex electrons promising for numerous
applications in material science, chemistry, and particle
physics [3â€“5]. However, in particle physics, specifically,
electrons are required with energies in the GeV range,
whereas the highest energy achieved for a vortex electron
to date is only about 300 keV [3, 6, 7].
A straightforward approach to obtaining high-energy
vortex electrons is to first generate twisted electrons at
low energies and then accelerate them. While the curvi-
linear sections of accelerators are likely unsuitable since
they lack axial symmetry, linear accelerators (linacs) ap-
pear to be appropriate for this purpose. However, a crit-
ical question arises: do these particles preserve their vor-
ticity as they travel through the acceleratorâ€™s electromag-
netic fields? Specifically, could the small but inevitable
radiation losses in a linac lead to a significant decrease
in the particleâ€™s OAM?

A key assumption of our semiclassical model is that
the emission of very few soft photons does not change the
quantum state of the electron much. Its wave function is
assumed to evolve according to the SchrÂ¨ odinger equation
with a fixed external field, and the back-action of the
emitted radiation on this state is neglected.
To validate this assumption, we compare the energy
radiated during one cyclotron period,

still constitutes no more than 10âˆ’6 of the electronâ€™s trans-
verse energy. This confirms that the back-action of radia-
tion is negligible and robustly validates our semiclassical
treatment even for kilometer-scale acceleration.
The interval of characteristic time of loss of one OAM
quantum lies within the range 10 3 âˆ’10 27 seconds. QED
approach, applied in [21] to evaluate the lifetime of a
Landau state in the acceleratorâ€™s magnetic field, shows
similarly large results forH= 1 T and kinetic energies of
vortex particles around several MeV. This indicates the
relevancy of semiclassical calculations since, as results in
Ref. [21] also demonstrate, radiation of vortex electrons
transitioning through a solenoid carries negligibly small
intensity, and the theory predicts a large lifetime of the
considered NSLG states.
IV. DISCUSSION
Our semiclassical approach, which treats the electronâ€™s
wave function as a coherent â€charge cloudâ€, is central
to an ongoing debate in the literature on how to model
single-particle radiation [22â€“25]. An alternative perspec-
tive suggests an incoherent model, where radiation in-
tensity is integrated over the probability distribution.
Experimentally distinguishing between these competing
theoretical frameworks â€” for instance, using a TEM â€”
remains a crucial open challenge and a promising direc-
tion for future research.
Our semiclassical results must also be considered in the
context of a full QED treatment, which includes sponta-
neous quantum transitions between energy levels â€”â€“ a
channel absent in our model. We hypothesize that a rig-
orous QED calculation for an NSLG state would reveal
both this â€quantumâ€ radiation and the classical compo-
nent from the wave packetâ€™s dynamics. This raises funda-
mental questions about how these two contributions are
encoded within QED, whether they can be separated,
and how they might interfere.
Plausibly, for â€sufficiently nonstationaryâ€ states, the
â€classicalâ€ radiation mechanism we describe might dom-
inate over the â€œquantumâ€ one. A critical open question is
the quantitative criterion for this classical regime, which
is supposed to be a condition likeÏƒ st âˆ’Ïƒ L â‰«Ïƒ L.
A final practical consideration is the radiation from the
solenoidâ€™s fringe fields. As detailed in Appendix C, the
inhomogeneous fields in this region generate a transient
burst of radiation with possibly high values of angular
momentum as the electron enters and exits. Crucially,
this transition signal is experimentally distinguishable
from the continuous, periodic radiation generated within
the uniform field. This separation allows for a clear ex-
perimental test of our central predictions for the steady-
state emission.8
V. CONCLUSION
In this work, we have developed a semiclassical model
to investigate the radiation emitted by a vortex elec-
tron propagating through a longitudinal magnetic field,
such as in a linear accelerator. Our key finding is that
both the radiated energy and the change in the electronâ€™s
OAM are extremely small for realistic accelerator param-
eters. Even when extrapolated to a kilometer-scale linac,
the total energy radiated remains a negligible fraction of
the electronâ€™s transverse energy, which in turn validates
our semiclassical approach. More importantly, the total
change in OAM is found to be minuscule, far less than a
single quantum ofâ„. In other words, we have found that
a single quantum of OAM is emitted in a typical time of
at least 103 seconds, much longer than the acceleration
time even in a km-long linac.
We therefore arrive at a clear and impactful conclu-
sion: the orbital angular momentum of vortex electrons
is remarkably robust during acceleration in linacs. This
result strongly supports the viability of using linacs to
produce high-energy, relativistic vortex electron beams
for future applications in materials science and particle
physics.

title: Impact of anisotropy on QCD phase structure and transport coefficients of quark matter
abstract:
Employing the Polyakov chiral SU(3) mean field (PCQMF) model, we investigate
how momentum-space anisotropy, characteristic of quark-gluon plasma (QGP) in
ultrarelativistic heavy-ion collisions (uRHIC), impacts the thermodynamic
behavior and transport coefficients of strongly interacting quark matter. The
momentum anisotropy is introduced via a small deformation in the momentum
distribution, quantified by a spheroidal parameter $\xi$, which deforms the
distribution functions and captures anisotropic effects to linear order. The
PCQMF model captures key non-perturbative aspects of QCD, like chiral symmetry
breaking, deconfinement dynamics through Polyakov loop potential, and is
extended here to accommodate momentum-space anisotropy. We compute the
modifications induced by momentum-space anisotropy to key thermodynamic
observables including pressure $p$, energy density $\epsilon$, entropy density
$s$, speed of sound squared $c_s^2$, and specific heat $c_v$, alongside key
transport coefficients, such as shear viscosity $\eta$, bulk viscosity
$\zeta_b$, and electrical conductivity $\sigma_{el}$. These coefficients are
derived using the relativistic Boltzmann equation (RBE) under the relaxation
time approximation (RTA). We find that even a weak anisotropy can lead to
significant modifications in the thermodynamic response and transport behavior
of quark matter. This underscores the importance of including momentum
anisotropy for realistic modeling of the QCD medium across all energy regimes,
from current studies at RHIC and LHC to future explorations of the high-density
frontier at FAIR, NICA, and J-PARC.

arXiv:2509.21186v1  [hep-ph]  25 Sep 2025I. INTRODUCTION
Ultrarelativistic heavy-ion collision (uRHIC) experiments, carried out at the Relativistic
Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) and the Large Hadron Collider (LHC), have been instrumental in
creating and studying the QGP , a state of matter where quarks and gluons are deconfined [1â€“
4]. The asymmetric initial geometry in non-central collisions and rapid expansion of the QGP
lead to anisotropic pressure gradients, and the momentum distribution of emitted particles
becomes anisotropic in the local rest frame [ 5, 6]. In particular, the medium expands more
along one direction than others, leading to unequal pressures (and particle yields) in different
azimuthal directions, and this anisotropy may persist through much of the QGPâ€™s evolution
[7]. This anisotropy is reflected in the momentum distribution of produced particles and
quantified using F ourier coeï¬€icients vn of the azimuthal distribution of emitted particles.
The second harmonic (elliptic flow v2) and third harmonic (triangular flow v3) have been
measured extensively at RHIC and LHC, providing direct evidence of anisotropic collective
expansion [8]. This indicates that the QGP , behaving nearly as an ideal fluid, retains memory
of the initial geometry through much of its evolution.
Momentum anisotropy is expected to influence the thermodynamic and transport prop-
erties of QCD matter, especially at finite temperature and non-zero chemical potentials.
While lattice QCD (LQCD) calculations indicate that the transition from QGP to hadrons
is a smooth crossover at low baryon density [9â€“15], the notorious sign problem limits LQCD
at high density [ 16], so one must rely on QCD low-energy effective models to explore this
regime. In the literature, these models are widely used to explore the phase structure of
dense matter, and they generally predict the existence of a first-order chiral phase tran-
sition terminating in a critical end point (CEP) [ 17â€“22]. Experimental facilities such as
NICA at JINR (Russia) [ 23], F AIR at GSI (Germany), including its CBM [24] and P ANDA
[25] experiments, as well as J-P ARC (Japan) [ 26], aim to provide critical insights into the
properties of QCD matter at high baryon densities. Effective models provide a controlled
framework to include essential QCD features such as spontaneous chiral symmetry break-
ing and confinement. These include the quark-meson coupling (QMC) model [ 27, 28], the
Polyakov-loop extended QMC (PQMC) model [ 29], the Nambu-Jona-Lasinio (NJL) model
[30, 31], the Polyakov NJL (PNJL) model [ 32, 33], the linear sigma model (LSM) [ 34], its
2Polyakov extended version PLSM [ 35], the chiral SU(3) quark mean field model (CQMF)
[36], and Polyakov CQMF (PCQMF) model [ 37]. In addition, other approaches such as the
functional renormalization group approach [38, 39] and Dyson-Schwinger equation approach
[40] have also been proposed to probe the behaviour of QCD at finite chemical potentials.
These models have been widely applied to investigate the thermodynamic [41] and transport
properties [ 42, 43] of strongly interacting matter.
Recent model developments account for effects such as strong magnetic and electric fields
[44â€“51], finite volume [52â€“58], non-extensivity [59, 60], and vorticity [61, 62] to faithfully cap-
ture the complexity of the QCD matter produced in uRHIC. Conventionally , these models
have relied on the assumption that quark matter remains perfectly isotropic in momentum
space in the absence of magnetic fields. However, realistic QGP is inherently anisotropic
due to initial geometric asymmetry and unequal expansion dynamics along the longitudinal
(beam) and transverse directions of the medium. Initial spatial anisotropy causes signif-
icantly lower pressure along the longitudinal direction, resulting in faster expansion and
cooling along the beam direction [ 7]. As a result, the transverse momenta of particles dom-
inate significantly over longitudinal momenta, making the parton momentum distributions
anisotropic [ 63]. Hydrodynamic and AdS/CFT analyses, as well as classical Y angâ€“Mills
simulations within the color-glass-condensate framework [5, 64â€“66], all indicate that the mo-
mentum anisotropy persists for at least Ï„ â‰² 2 fm/c, with pressure ratios PL/PT well below
unity . These results show that a realistic phenomenological analysis of strongly interacting
matter must incorporate momentum anisotropy .
The anisotropic momentum distributions not only modifies the local properties of the
QGP but also induces chromo-W eibel instabilities associated with color collective modes,
driving rapid redistribution of energy and momentum, thereby shaping the QGPâ€™s early-
time evolution and subsequent hydrodynamic behavior [ 67â€“70]. In practice, momentum
anisotropy is typically modelled by a parameter Î¾, which encodes the degree of deformation
along a specified direction, effectively quantifying the extent to which the distribution is
stretched or compressed relative to isotropy . This approach, first developed by Romatschke
and Strickland [7], has since become a central tool in kinetic and hydrodynamic treatments
of anisotropic QGP . Numerous studies have explored how momentum anisotropy alters key
observables, from photon and dilepton yields [ 71â€“73] to parton self-energies [ 74, 75], heavy-
3quark potentials [76â€“78], quarkonium states [79â€“81], jet-quenching coeï¬€icients [82], and fun-
damental transport coeï¬€icients [ 83, 84], as well as non-equilibrium hydrodynamic behavior
[85].
Momentum anisotropy can significantly modify the equation of state and the transport
properties of the QGP . T ransport coeï¬€icients, such as shear viscosityÎ·, bulk viscosity Î¶b, and
electrical conductivity Ïƒel, which govern the QGPâ€™s response to gradients and external fields,
are known to be particularly sensitive to anisotropic effects. Recent studies have explored
these effects on QCD matter using various effective models. F or instance, a 2+1 flavor quark-
meson (QM) model showed that increasing the anisotropy parameter, Î¾, suppresses Î·and Ïƒel
and leads to a nontrivial behavior inÎ¶b [86]. A similar reduction in viscosity and conductivity
was confirmed using a quasiparticle relaxation time approximation (R T A) to the Boltzmann
equation [ 87]. Within the PNJL model, Ref. [ 84] found that anisotropy amplified baryon-
number fluctuations, enhancing kurtosis, skewness, and deforming isentropic trajectories.
Ref. [ 83] showed that Ïƒel increases with temperature but is suppressed by anisotropy in a
quasiparticle R T A setup. In a three-flavor PQM analysis impact of finite anisotropy on nature
of phase transition has been explored in Ref. [ 88]. The above various studies underscore
the importance of incorporating momentum-space anisotropy for accurately describing the
thermodynamic properties and transport coeï¬€icients of QCD matter.
Motivated by this, we aim to examine the influence of momentum anisotropy on the ther-
modynamic observables and transport coeï¬€icients of strongly interacting matter within the
Polyakov chiral SU(3) quark mean field (PCQMF) model, across a wide range of temper-
atures and chemical potentials relevant to heavy-ion collisions. The PCQMF model is an
effective framework that incorporates both chiral and deconfinement dynamics by including
Polyakov loop variables in a three-flavor chiral mean field model. It contains quark inter-
actions with scalar and vector meson fields, which drive chiral symmetry breaking and its
restoration, along with a Polyakov loop potential that effectively captures gluon dynamics
for confinement. This approach effectively reproduces QCD thermodynamics across a range
of temperatures and chemical potentials [ 89]. It has been used to study the fluctuations of
conserved charges [90], nonextensive [91], finite-volume effects [92], and properties of nuclear
as well as quark stars [93, 94]. The momentum-space anisotropy is incorporated via a dimen-
sionless parameter Î¾, which quantifies the extent of deformation along a specific direction,
4thereby capturing deviations from local isotropy in the medium. Employing the anisotropic
PCQMF framework, we compute key thermodynamic quantities, including pressure, energy
density , entropy density , speed of sound, and specific heat. W e then calculate transport co-
eï¬€icients, such as shear viscosity , bulk viscosity , and electrical conductivity , by solving the
relativistic Boltzmann equation (RBE) within the R T A under anisotropic conditions. W e as-
sume an isotropic relaxation time Ï„, following standard practice, and discuss the implications
and limitations of this assumption in the section II C. It should be noted that implementing
anisotropy affects only the momentum dependence within distribution functions and does
not introduce new fundamental interactions. Additionally , we restrict ourselves to a weakly
anisotropic medium, i.e., |Î¾| <1, allowing us to expand the anisotropic distribution function
linearly around its isotropic equilibrium form. This enables us to decompose the transport
coeï¬€icients explicitly into isotropic contributions and anisotropic corrections [ 83].
The remainder of this paper is structured as follows. In Sec. II A, we outline the theo-
retical framework of the PCQMF model. The incorporation of momentum-space anisotropy
into the PCQMF model is presented in Sec. II B. Anisotropic expressions of the transport
coeï¬€icients are derived in Sec. II C. In Sec. III, we examine the influence of momentum
anisotropy on the thermodynamic and transport properties of the medium, with compar-
isons to available lattice QCD results. Finally , Sec. IV summarizes our findings and offers
physical interpretations of the observed effects.
II. METHODOLOGY
In this section, we detail the theoretical framework employed to investigate the impact
of momentum anisotropy on the thermodynamic and transport properties of quark matter
and its implications on the QCD phase diagram. W e begin with an overview of the PCQMF
model. Then, we outline the procedure for incorporating momentum anisotropy into the
model and derive the anisotropic expressions for shear viscosity , bulk viscosity , and electrical
conductivity by employing the RBE within R T A.

IV. SUMMAR Y
In this work, we have presented a comprehensive analysis of the impact of momentum-
space anisotropy on the thermodynamic equation of state, and transport properties of
strongly interacting quark matter. Employing the Polyakov chiral SU(3) quark mean field
25(PCQMF) model, which captures both chiral symmetry dynamics and quark confinement
through a Polyakov loop potential, we introduce anisotropy via a spheroidal deformation in
the momentum distribution, quantified by the parameter Î¾. A system with a â€œsqueezedâ€ or
oblate momentum distribution (Î¾ >0) preferentially populates transverse momentum states,
characteristic of the rapid longitudinal expansion in the early stages of heavy-ion collisions.
While a â€œstretchedâ€ or prolate distribution (Î¾ <0) favors momenta along the anisotropy axis,
a scenario expected to arise in the presence of a strong magnetic field, with Î¾ =0 represent-
ing the isotropic case. Our investigation reveals that even weak anisotropy profoundly alters
the systemâ€™s characteristics. W e find that key thermodynamic observables like pressure,
energy density , entropy density , squared speed of sound, and specific heat are systemati-
cally suppressed for squeezed systems ( Î¾ >0) and enhanced for stretched ones ( Î¾ <0) when
compared to the isotropic case at the same temperature. This demonstrates that the mo-
mentum distribution fundamentally modifies the available phase space and thus alters the
bulk thermodynamic properties and the equation of state of the medium.
F urthermore, the transport coeï¬€icients, calculated by solving the relativistic Boltzmann
equation in the relaxation time approximation, exhibit a strong and systematic depen-
dence on this anisotropy . The specific shear viscosity ( Î·aniso/s) and electrical conductiv-
ity ( Ïƒel,aniso/T) are significantly suppressed for squeezed distributions ( Î¾ >0), pushing the
system closer to the â€œperfect fluidâ€ ideal and hindering charge transport, respectively . Con-
versely , these coeï¬€icients are enhanced for stretched distributions (Î¾ <0). The bulk viscosity
(Î¶b,aniso/s) shows a similar, though less pronounced, trend, with its characteristic peak near
the phase transition shifting in temperature and magnitude according to the value of Î¾. At
a finite baryon chemical potential of ÂµB = 400 Me V, the absolute magnitudes ofÎ·aniso/sand
Î¶b,aniso/schange, with shear viscosity increasing while bulk viscosity is suppressed. However,
the qualitative dependence on the sign of Î¾ remains the same. Collectively , these results un-
derscore that momentum-space anisotropy is a crucial physical feature that fundamentally
reshapes the properties of the quark-gluon plasma. Even when weak, it induces signifi-
cant modifications in both thermodynamic and transport properties of the QCD medium.
The thermodynamic responses are suppressed for positive Î¾. The transport coeï¬€icients are
modified significantly with Î¾, especially near the transition temperature, highlighting the
anisotropic redistribution of microscopic transport. Its inclusion is therefore essential for
26the realistic phenomenological modeling of the early-time, pre-equilibrium dynamics in ul-
trarelativistic heavy-ion collisions at facilities like RHIC, the LHC, F AIR, and NICA, and
for accurately bridging theoretical predictions with experimental data.

Abstract Content:
Employing the Polyakov chiral SU(3) mean field (PCQMF) model, we investigate
how momentum-space anisotropy, characteristic of quark-gluon plasma (QGP) in
ultrarelativistic heavy-ion collisions (uRHIC), impacts the thermodynamic
behavior and transport coefficients of strongly interacting quark matter. The
momentum anisotropy is introduced via a small deformation in the momentum
distribution, quantified by a spheroidal parameter $\xi$, which deforms the
distribution functions and captures anisotropic effects to linear order. The
